title: Income and Age
question_text:
A sociologist polled random individuals and asked them their age and annual income. The results are shown in the chart above.
Which of the following statements is true concerning data from this chart?
tables:
< $25,000$25,001- $50,000$50,001- $100,000$100,000+
Ages 25 and under224076
Ages 25-341932118
Ages 35-4417182016
Ages 45-543184014
Ages 54 and up1162515

choices.text: There seems to be an association between frequency and age, as more individuals polled are under $25$ years old than any other group.
There seems to be a relatively even distribution of income among $35$- to $44$-year-olds.
There seems to be a relatively even distribution of ages for those who make $\$25,001$ to $\$50,000$.
This chart may serve as evidence that a jump in age causes higher income.
Among all ages combined, it appears that income is evenly distributed.

solution:
We can see the income distribution of 35âˆ’44
-year-olds is 24%,25.4%,28.2%,and22.5%
, which are all relatively equal.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect; conclusions of associations cannot be drawn with frequency.

Choice 'C' is incorrect; the distribution of ages is NOT even for this income bracket: 32.3%,25.8%,14.5%,14.5%
, and 12.9%
.

Choice 'D' is incorrect. this chart does not contain data from an experiment; therefore, we cannot assume a causal relationship.

Choice 'E' is incorrect; the distribution is not even: 17.8%,35.6%,29.6%,17%
.
